sen.j: 昭憲皇太后（しょうけんこうたいごう、1849年4月17日 (旧暦)（新暦5月9日） - 1914年4月9日）は、日本の皇族。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken (May 9, 1849 – April 9, 1914) was a member of the Japan's Imperial family.
Empress Dowager Shoken (May 9, 1849 – April 9, 1914) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family.
Empress Dowager Shoken (May 9, 1849 – April 9, 1914) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family.

sen.j: 明治天皇の皇后。
sen.e: She was the empress of Emperor Meiji.
She was the empress of Emperor Meiji.
She was the empress of Emperor Meiji.

sen.j: 名は、一条美子（いちじょう はるこ）。
sen.e: Her name was Haruko ICHIJO.
Her name was Haruko ICHIJO.
Her name was Haruko ICHIJO.

sen.j: お印は若葉（わかば）。
sen.e: Her oshirushi (signature mark used by members of the Imperial family to mark their belongings) was a young leaf.
Her oshirushi (signature mark used by members of the Imperial family to mark their belongings) was a young leaf (Wakaba).
Her oshirushi (signature mark used by members of the Imperial family to mark their belongings) was a young leaf (Wakaba).

sen.j: 病弱で実子はなかったが、嫡妻として、夫の側室が生んだ大正天皇を養子とした。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken had a weak constitution and did not have a biological child, but as a lawful wife she adopted the child of her husband's concubine.
Empress Dowager Shoken was sickly and did not have a biological child, but as a lawful wife she adopted the child (Emperor Taisho) between her husband and his concubine.
sen.cmt: weak constitution ⇒ sickly 側室の子大正天皇 のところを、彼女の夫と側室の子（大正天皇） に訂正しました。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken was sickly and did not have a biological child, but as a lawful wife she adopted the child (Emperor Taisho) between her husband and his concubine.

sen.j: 嘉永2年（1849年）4月17日誕生。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken was born on April 17, 1849.
Empress Dowager Shoken was born on April 17, 1849.
Empress Dowager Shoken was born on April 17, 1849.

sen.j: 従一位左大臣一条忠香の三女で、生母は側室新畑民子（忠香の正室は伏見宮順子女王）。
sen.e: She was the third daughter of Juichii-sadaijin Tadaka ICHIJO, and her real mother was Tamiko NIIHATA, a concubine (Tadaka's lawful wife was Princess Fushimi no miya Junko).
She was the third daughter of Juichii-sadaijin Tadaka ICHIJO, and her real mother was Tamiko NIIHATA, a concubine (Tadaka's lawful wife was Princess Fushimi no miya Junko).
She was the third daughter of Juichii-sadaijin Tadaka ICHIJO, and her real mother was Tamiko NIIHATA, a concubine (Tadaka's lawful wife was Princess Fushimi no miya Junko).

sen.j: 右大臣一条実良（1835－1868年）の妹。
sen.e: She was the younger sister of the Minister of the Right, Saneyoshi ICHIJO.
She was the younger sister of the Minister of the Right, Saneyoshi ICHIJO (1835 - 1868).
She was the younger sister of the Minister of the Right, Saneyoshi ICHIJO (1835 - 1868).

sen.j: 徳川慶喜の婚約者であった千代君（照姫）は実の姉であり、千代君に代わって慶喜に嫁いだ一条美賀子（忠香養女、実は今出川公久の娘）とも義理の姉妹となる。
sen.e: Chiyogimi (Teruhime), Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA's fiancée, was Empress Dowager Shoken's older sister, and Mikako ICHIJO (adopted daughter of Tadaka, biological daughter of Kinhisa IMADEGAWA), who married Yoshinobu instead of Chiyogimi, was her step-sister.

Chiyogimi (Teruhime), Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA's fiancée, was Empress Dowager Shoken's older sister, and Mikako ICHIJO (adopted daughter of Tadaka, biological daughter of Kinhisa IMADEGAWA), who married Yoshinobu instead of Chiyogimi, was her step-sister.

Chiyogimi (Teruhime), Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA's fiancée, was Empress Dowager Shoken's older sister, and Mikako ICHIJO (adopted daughter of Tadaka, biological daughter of Kinhisa IMADEGAWA), who married Yoshinobu instead of Chiyogimi, was her step-sister.

sen.j: はじめの諱は勝子（まさこ）。
sen.e: Her first posthumous name was Masako.
Her first imina (personal name) was Masako.
Her first imina (personal name) was Masako.

sen.j: 通称は富貴君（ふきぎみ）、富美君（ふみぎみ）など。
sen.e: Her common names were Fukigimi and Fumigimi, and such.
Her common names were Fukigimi, Fumigimi, and such.
sen.cmt: and をひとつ削除しました。
sen.e: Her common names were Fukigimi, Fumigimi, and such.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）6月、寿栄君（すえぎみ）と改名。
sen.e: She changed her name to Suegimi in June 1858.
She changed her name to Suegimi in June 1858.
She changed her name to Suegimi in June 1858.

sen.j: 慶応3年6月28日 (旧暦)（1867年7月29日）、新帝明治天皇の女御に治定。
sen.e: On July 29, 1867, she was authorized as the emperor's consort.
On July 29, 1867, she was authorized as the new Emperor Meiji's consort.
sen.cmt: 新帝明治天皇が天皇のみになっていたため、訂正しました。
sen.e: On July 29, 1867, she was authorized as the new Emperor Meiji's consort.

sen.j: 伏見宮家の縁故で、女流漢学者で勤王論者の若江薫子（1835―1881年）が家庭教師として忠香の娘たちの養育に携わっていたが、女御を一条家から出すのに際し、薫子は姉を差し置いて妹の寿栄君を推薦したと言われている。
sen.e: Through connections of the Fushimi-no-Miya family, Nioko WAKAE, a female scholar of Chinese classics and an imperialist (1835-1881), took part in the nurturing of Tadaka's daughters as a tutor, but in the face of choosing a consort from the ICHIJO family, Nioko is said to have chosen the younger sister Suegimi over the older sister.

Through connections of the Fushimi-no-Miya family, Nioko WAKAE, a female scholar of Chinese classics and an imperialist (1835-1881), was involved in the nurturing of Tadaka's daughters as a tutor, but in the face of choosing a consort from the ICHIJO family, Nioko is said to have recommended the younger sister Suegimi over the older sister.
sen.cmt: took part in ⇒ was involved in, chosen ⇒ recommended
sen.e: Through connections of the Fushimi-no-Miya family, Nioko WAKAE, a female scholar of Chinese classics and an imperialist (1835-1881), was involved in the nurturing of Tadaka's daughters as a tutor, but in the face of choosing a consort from the ICHIJO family, Nioko is said to have recommended the younger sister Suegimi over the older sister.

sen.j: 明治元年12月26日 (旧暦)（1869年2月7日）、美子（はるこ）と改名。
sen.e: On Febuary 7, 1869, she changed her name to Haruko.
On Febuary 7, 1869, she changed her name to Haruko.
On Febuary 7, 1869, she changed her name to Haruko.

sen.j: 12月28日 (旧暦)（1869年2月9日）入内して女御の宣下を蒙り、即日皇后に立てられた。
sen.e: On Feburary 9, 1869, Shoken entered the court and obtained imperial proclamation to become a consort, and on the same day she became empress.
On Feburary 9, 1869, Shoken entered the court and obtained imperial proclamation to become a consort, and on the same day she became an empress.
sen.cmt: empress の前に anを追加しました。
sen.e: On Feburary 9, 1869, Shoken entered the court and obtained imperial proclamation to become a consort, and on the same day she became an empress.

sen.j: この際、天皇より3歳年長であることを忌避して、公式には嘉永3年（1850年）の出生とされた。
sen.e: On this occasion, to avoid the fact that Shoken was three years older than the Emperor, her official birth year became 1850.
On this occasion, to avoid the fact that Shoken was three years older than the Emperor, her birth year was officially announced as1850.
On this occasion, to avoid the fact that Shoken was three years older than the Emperor, her birth year was officially announced as1850.

sen.j: 当初、中世以来の慣行に従って中宮職を付置され、中宮と称されたが、翌年、中宮職が皇后宮職に改められ、称号も皇后宮と改められた。
sen.e: In the beginning, she was placed in the Chugushiki (Office of the Consort's Household) and was called Chugu following the tradition from the Medieval Period, but in the following year, the Chugushiki was changed to Kogogushiki (Queen-consort's Household Agency) and her title also changed to Kisai no Miya (empress).

In the beginning, she was placed in the Chugushiki (Office of the Consort's Household) and was called Chugu following the tradition from the Medieval Period, but in the following year, the Chugushiki was changed to Kogogushiki (Queen-consort's Household Agency) and her title also changed to Kisai no Miya (empress).

In the beginning, she was placed in the Chugushiki (Office of the Consort's Household) and was called Chugu following the tradition from the Medieval Period, but in the following year, the Chugushiki was changed to Kogogushiki (Queen-consort's Household Agency) and her title also changed to Kisai no Miya (empress).

sen.j: このときを最後に、中宮職は廃止され、中宮の称号も絶えた。
sen.e: The Chugushiki was abolished with this as it's last, and the Chugu title also ceased.
The Chugushiki has been abolished since then, and the Chugu title also ceased.
sen.cmt: このときを最後に： 現在完了＋since then の形に訂正しました。
sen.e: The Chugushiki has been abolished since then, and the Chugu title also ceased.

sen.j: 1914年（大正3年）4月9日午前2時10分、沼津御用邸にて崩御。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken died on April 9, 1914 at 2:10 AM, at the Numazu Imperial Villa.
Empress Dowager Shoken died on April 9, 1914 at 2:10 AM, at the Numazu Imperial Villa.
Empress Dowager Shoken died on April 9, 1914 at 2:10 AM, at the Numazu Imperial Villa.

sen.j: 公式には4月11日同時刻。
sen.e: Officially, her death is dated April 11 at the same time.
Officially, her date of death is April 11 at the same time.
sen.cmt: 公式死亡日 という表現に訂正しました。
sen.e: Officially, her date of death is April 11 at the same time.

sen.j: まる2日ずらされたのは、宮内省内蔵頭当時の収賄で司直の手が及びかけていた渡辺千秋宮内大臣を急遽更迭させるための措置。
sen.e: This official date was put as two days later than the real date as a measure to quickly replace Minister of the Imperial Households Chiaki WATANABE, whom the arm of the law was catching up to for his usage of bribery during his time as the Chief of Kuraryo of the Imperial Household Ministry.

This official date was put off by two days from the real date as a measure to quickly replace Minister of the Imperial Households Chiaki WATANABE, who was almost in the reach of the law for his usage of bribery during his time as the Chief of Kuraryo of the Imperial Household Ministry.
sen.cmt: put as ⇒ put off by (laterを削除）, than ⇒ from, 司直の手が、、、：whom the arm of the law was catching up to ⇒ who was almost in the reach of the law
sen.e: This official date was put off by two days from the real date as a measure to quickly replace Minister of the Imperial Households Chiaki WATANABE, who was almost in the reach of the law for his usage of bribery during his time as the Chief of Kuraryo of the Imperial Household Ministry.

sen.j: 大喪最高責任者となるはずの渡辺が大喪の終るまでの約3ヶ月の間にもし逮捕されると、宮内省の威信が地に落ちると考えられたためと思われる。
sen.e: This measure is thought to be taken due to the belief that if WATANABE, who was the chief officer of the Imperial mourning, was arrested during the time of the Imperial mourning which lasts about three months, the Imperial Household Ministry's dignity would hit rock bottom.

This measure is thought to be taken due to the belief that if WATANABE, who was the chief officer of the Imperial mourning, was arrested during the time of the Imperial mourning which lasts for about three months, the Imperial Household Ministry's dignity would be lost.
sen.cmt: 約３ヶ月： for を追加しました。地に落ちる： be lostに訂正しました。
sen.e: This measure is thought to be taken due to the belief that if WATANABE, who was the chief officer of the Imperial mourning, was arrested during the time of the Imperial mourning which lasts for about three months, the Imperial Household Ministry's dignity would be lost.

sen.j: 同年5月9日、宮内省告示第9号により「昭憲皇太后」と追号され、翌年5月1日に、明治天皇とともに明治神宮の祭神とされた。
sen.e: On May 9 of the same year, by the Imperial Household Ministry notification no. 9, Shoken was given the posthumous title "Empress Dowager Shoken," and on May 1 of the following year, she was enshrined along with Emperor Meiji in the Meiji-jingu Shrine.

On May 9 of the same year, by the Imperial Household Ministry notification no. 9, Shoken was given the posthumous title "Empress Dowager Shoken," and on May 1 of the following year, she was enshrined along with Emperor Meiji in the Meiji-jingu Shrine.

On May 9 of the same year, by the Imperial Household Ministry notification no. 9, Shoken was given the posthumous title "Empress Dowager Shoken," and on May 1 of the following year, she was enshrined along with Emperor Meiji in the Meiji-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 陵墓は伏見桃山東陵（ふしみももやまのひがしのみささぎ）。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken's imperial mausoleum is in Fushimi Momoyama Higashi no Misaki.
Empress Dowager Shoken's imperial mausoleum is in Fushimi Momoyama Higashi no Misaki.
Empress Dowager Shoken's imperial mausoleum is in Fushimi Momoyama Higashi no Misaki.

sen.j: 業績
sen.e: Achievements
Achievements
Achievements

sen.j: 維新期の皇后として社会事業振興の先頭に立ち、華族女学校（現学習院女子部）や、お茶の水の東京女子師範学校（現お茶の水女子大学）の設立、日本赤十字社の発展などに大きく寄与した（赤十字社の正式紋章「赤十字桐竹鳳凰章」は、紋章制定の相談を受けた際、皇后がたまたま被っていた冠が桐と竹の組み合わせで出来ていた事から、「これがよかろう」という事で決められたという）。
sen.e: As an empress after the Restoration, Shoken took the lead as a promoter of social work and greatly contributed to the establishment of Kazoku Jogakko (present day Gakushuin School Corporation Girl's Division) and Tokyo Joshi Shikan Gakko (present day Ochanomizu University), along with the development of the Japanese Red Cross Society and others (it is said that the official crest for the Red Cross Society, the "Red Cross Kiritake Phoenix," was decided on from the crown, made by a combination of paulownia wood and bamboo, which Shoken happened to be wearing on the occasion she was consulted on for the decision of the crest.

As an empress after the Restoration, Shoken took the lead in social work promotion and greatly contributed to the establishment of Kazoku Jogakko (present day Gakushuin School Corporation Girl's Division) and Tokyo Joshi Shikan Gakko (present day Ochanomizu University), along with the development of the Japanese Red Cross Society and others (it is said that the official crest for the Red Cross Society, the "Red Cross Kiritake Phoenix," was decided on from the crown, made by a combination of paulownia wood and bamboo, which Shoken happened to be wearing on the occasion she was consulted for the decision of the crest.
sen.cmt: 社会事業振興の先頭に立ち：as a promoter of ⇒ in social work promotion, consulted on for ⇒ onを削除しました。
sen.e: As an empress after the Restoration, Shoken took the lead in social work promotion and greatly contributed to the establishment of Kazoku Jogakko (present day Gakushuin School Corporation Girl's Division) and Tokyo Joshi Shikan Gakko (present day Ochanomizu University), along with the development of the Japanese Red Cross Society and others (it is said that the official crest for the Red Cross Society, the "Red Cross Kiritake Phoenix," was decided on from the crown, made by a combination of paulownia wood and bamboo, which Shoken happened to be wearing on the occasion she was consulted for the decision of the crest.

sen.j: 津田梅子ら女子留学生の派遣にも大きく関わったとされている。
sen.e: It is said that Shoken was also greatly involved in the dispatch of female study abroad students, such as Umeko TSUDA.
It is said that Shoken was also greatly involved in the dispatch of female study abroad students, such as Umeko TSUDA.
It is said that Shoken was also greatly involved in the dispatch of female study abroad students, such as Umeko TSUDA.

sen.j: 皇后として欧化政策の先頭に立たなければいけない立場を強く自覚しており、1886年（明治19年）以降は、着用の衣服を寝間着を除いてすべて洋服に切り替えた。
sen.e: She was strongly aware of her position as a leader in the policy of Europeanization, and after 1886, she changed all her clothes she wore, except nightclothes, to western clothing.
She was strongly aware of her position as an empress to lead the policy of Europeanization, and after 1886, she changed all her clothes she wore, except nightclothes, to western clothing.
sen.cmt: 皇后として： as an empress to lead を追加
sen.e: She was strongly aware of her position as an empress to lead the policy of Europeanization, and after 1886, she changed all her clothes she wore, except nightclothes, to western clothing.

sen.j: 洋服を率先着用した理由としてもう一つ「上半身と下半身の分かれていない着物は女子の行動を制限して不自由である」という皇后自身の言葉も伝えられている。
sen.e: As another reason for taking the lead in wearing western clothes, the empress herself was quoted as saying"Kimono that does not have a separation between the upper and lower parts of the body limits a girl's movements and is inconvenient."

As another reason for taking the lead in wearing western clothes, the empress herself was quoted as saying"Kimono that is not separated into upper and lower parts limits a girl's movements and is inconvenient."
sen.cmt: 上半身と下半身の分かれていない： isn't separated into upper and lower parts に訂正しました。
sen.e: As another reason for taking the lead in wearing western clothes, the empress herself was quoted as saying"Kimono that is not separated into upper and lower parts limits a girl's movements and is inconvenient."

sen.j: 現在の皇室で意外なほど和服が着られないのは、この時の方針が踏襲されているからである。
sen.e: The reason why the present Imperial family wears Japanese traditional clothes surprisingly less often than expected is because they are following this policy.
The reason why the present Imperial family wears Japanese traditional clothes surprisingly less often than expected is because they are following this policy.
The reason why the present Imperial family wears Japanese traditional clothes surprisingly less often than expected is because they are following this policy.

sen.j: また、生涯に3万首を超える和歌を詠み、その一部が『昭憲皇太后御集』として伝わる。
sen.e: Furthermore, Shoken composed more than thirty thousand Japanese poems, and some of this is handed down as "Empress Dowager Shoken's Gyoshu"
Furthermore, Shoken composed more than thirty thousands Japanese poems, and some of them are handed down as "Empress Dowager Shoken's Gyoshu"
sen.cmt: thousand に複数形のs を追加しました。 some of this is ⇒ some of them are, ” ” ⇒ ' ' に訂正しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, Shoken composed more than thirty thousands Japanese poems, and some of them are handed down as "Empress Dowager Shoken's Gyoshu"

sen.j: 昭憲皇太后の御歌としては、1876年（明治9年）2月、東京女子師範学校に下賜した校歌「磨かずば玉も鏡もなにかせむ学びの道もかくこそありけれ」（玉も鏡も磨かなければ何にもならない。
sen.e: As one of Empress Dowager Shoken's poems, a school song given to Tokyo Joshi Shihan Gakko "when not polished, jewels and mirrors are worthless, the way of studying is much the same way" (If you don't polish a jewel or mirror they won't do much good.

As one of Empress Dowager Shoken's poems, a school song given to Tokyo Joshi Shihan Gakko 'when not polished, jewels and mirrors are worthless, the way of studying is much the same way' (If you don't polish a jewel or mirror they won't do much good.

As one of Empress Dowager Shoken's poems, a school song given to Tokyo Joshi Shihan Gakko 'when not polished, jewels and mirrors are worthless, the way of studying is much the same way' (If you don't polish a jewel or mirror they won't do much good.

sen.j: 勉強もそういうもの）が有名であり、また、華族女学校の教育指針を詠んだ「金剛石」「水は器」等も、尋常小学校唱歌として広く歌われた。
sen.e: Studying is the same way) is famous, and, "Kongouseki" and "Mizu no Utsuwa"and others, which read about education guidelines of Kazoku Jogakko, are also widely sang as songs of Jinjo Elementary School.

Studying is the same way) is famous, and, "Kongouseki" and "Mizu no Utsuwa"and others, which read about education guidelines of Kazoku Jogakko, are also widely sang as songs of Jinjo Elementary School.

Studying is the same way) is famous, and, "Kongouseki" and "Mizu no Utsuwa"and others, which read about education guidelines of Kazoku Jogakko, are also widely sang as songs of Jinjo Elementary School.

sen.j: 崩御に際して「ロンドンタイムズ」は彼女の功績を高く評価する記事を掲載した。
sen.e: At the time of her death, the "Los Angles Times" ran an article highly evaluating her great achievements.
At the time of her death, "Times of London" ran an article highly evaluating her great achievements.
sen.cmt: ロンドンタイムズがロサンジェルスタイムズになっていました。” ” ⇒ ' ' に訂正しました。
sen.e: At the time of her death, "Times of London" ran an article highly evaluating her great achievements.

sen.j: （出雲井晶『エピソードでつづる 昭憲皇太后』参照）。
sen.e: (Aki IZUMOI "Empress Dowager Shoken Through Episodes" referenced).
(Aki IZUMOI "Empress Dowager Shoken Through Episodes" referenced).
(Aki IZUMOI "Empress Dowager Shoken Through Episodes" referenced).

sen.j: 逸話
sen.e: Anecdotes
Anecdotes
Anecdotes

sen.j: 1884年（明治17年）に宮中改革を巡って明治天皇とギクシャクしていた伊藤博文が病気で倒れた際には、天皇に代わって見舞いの使者を出して両者の仲直りのきっかけを作った。
sen.e: When Hirobumi ITO, who was having a strained relationship with Emperor Meiji over the reform of the Imperial Court, was taken with illness, Empress Dowager Shoken sent an envoy on the behalf of the Emperor to ITO and made an opportunity for the two to reconcile.

When Hirobumi ITO, who was having a strained relationship with Emperor Meiji over the reform of the Imperial Court, was taken with illness, Empress Dowager Shoken sent an envoy on behalf of the Emperor to ITO and made an opportunity for the two to reconcile.
sen.cmt: on the behalf of ⇒ on behalf of
sen.e: When Hirobumi ITO, who was having a strained relationship with Emperor Meiji over the reform of the Imperial Court, was taken with illness, Empress Dowager Shoken sent an envoy on behalf of the Emperor to ITO and made an opportunity for the two to reconcile.

sen.j: また、同年に宮内大輔の吉井友実が以前に社長を務めていた日本鉄道の上野駅－高崎駅間開通式典に出席した際に、明治天皇は出席に乗り気ではなく天気も一日中雨であったが、皇后は終始笑顔で応対し吉井を感激させた（吉井の宮島誠一郎宛書簡）。
sen.e: Also in the same year, when Empress Dowager Shoken attended the opening ceremony of Nippon Railway Ueno Station – Takasaki Station, which Tomozane YOSHII who was the Kunai-taifu (post of Imperial Household Ministry) used to be president of, the empress handled the event with a smile throughout the whole time even though Emperor Meiji did not show much enthusiasm to attend and it was raining the whole day; YOSHII was greatly touched because of this (a letter written by YOSHII to Seiichi MIYAJIMA).

Also in the same year, when Empress Dowager Shoken attended the opening ceremony of Nippon Railway Ueno Station – Takasaki Station, which Tomozane YOSHII who was the Kunai-taifu (post of Imperial Household Ministry) used to be president of, the empress handled the event with a smile throughout the whole time even though Emperor Meiji did not show much enthusiasm to attend and it was raining all day; YOSHII was greatly touched because of this (a letter written by YOSHII to Seiichi MIYAJIMA).
sen.cmt: raining the whole day ⇒ raining all day
sen.e: Also in the same year, when Empress Dowager Shoken attended the opening ceremony of Nippon Railway Ueno Station – Takasaki Station, which Tomozane YOSHII who was the Kunai-taifu (post of Imperial Household Ministry) used to be president of, the empress handled the event with a smile throughout the whole time even though Emperor Meiji did not show much enthusiasm to attend and it was raining all day; YOSHII was greatly touched because of this (a letter written by YOSHII to Seiichi MIYAJIMA).

sen.j: 明治になって再び朝廷に政権が返った事により、江戸幕府の大奥や西洋の宮廷の例のように皇后やその周辺の側近が国政に関与する可能性も存在したが、彼女は自らを律して国政に直接関与する事を戒めた。
sen.e: Due to the return of political power to the court in Meiji, there was a possibility that the empress along with advisers close to the empress could take part in the national government, like the O-oku in the Edo Bakufu or the Imperial Court in Western countries, but the Empress disciplined herself and prohibited themselves from taking part in the national government.

Due to the return of political power to the court during Meiji Period, there was a possibility that the empress along with advisers close to the empress could take part in the national government, like the O-oku in the Edo Bakufu or the Imperial Court in Western countries, but the Empress disciplined herself and prohibited themselves from taking part in the national government.

Due to the return of political power to the court during Meiji Period, there was a possibility that the empress along with advisers close to the empress could take part in the national government, like the O-oku in the Edo Bakufu or the Imperial Court in Western countries, but the Empress disciplined herself and prohibited themselves from taking part in the national government.

sen.j: また、香川敬三や下田歌子などの周囲の側近に恵まれて、近代日本の皇后としての役割を確立することができた。
sen.e: Furthermore, Empress Dowager Shoken was blessed with close advisers around her, such as Keizou KAGAWA and Utako SHIMODA, and was able to establish her role as an empress in modern Japan.
Furthermore, Empress Dowager Shoken was blessed with close advisers around her, such as Keizou KAGAWA and Utako SHIMODA, and was able to establish her role as an empress in modern Japan.
Furthermore, Empress Dowager Shoken was blessed with close advisers around her, such as Keizou KAGAWA and Utako SHIMODA, and was able to establish her role as an empress in modern Japan.

sen.j: 1904年（明治37年）2月、日露戦争の前夜、葉山の御用邸に皇后が滞在していた折であったが、37,8歳の武士が白衣で皇后の夢枕に立ち、戦いの際の海軍 (日本)守護を誓ったという。
sen.e: In Feburary 1904, on the eve of the Russo-Japanese War, when the Empress was staying in the Imperial palace in Hayama, she said that a samurai about 37 or 38 years old wearing a white frock came into her dreams and swore the protection of the Japanese Navy at war.

In Feburary 1904, on the eve of the Russo-Japanese War, when the Empress was staying in the Imperial palace in Hayama, she said that a samurai about 37 or 38 years old wearing a white frock came into her dreams and swore the protection of the Japanese Navy at war.

In Feburary 1904, on the eve of the Russo-Japanese War, when the Empress was staying in the Imperial palace in Hayama, she said that a samurai about 37 or 38 years old wearing a white frock came into her dreams and swore the protection of the Japanese Navy at war.

sen.j: 皇后が侍臣に下問したところ、坂本龍馬の霊であるとわかった。
sen.e: When the Empress inquired a courtier, they realized this was the spirit of Ryoma SAKAMOTO.
When the Empress inquired a courtier, they realized this was the spirit of Ryoma SAKAMOTO.
When the Empress inquired a courtier, they realized this was the spirit of Ryoma SAKAMOTO.

sen.j: これが新聞に載って国民の士気を鼓舞し、京都霊山護国神社にある坂本龍馬の墓前に忠魂碑が立てられるに至った。
sen.e: This ran in the newspapers arousing the morale of the nation, which lead to the establishment of a monument for loyal souls in front of Ryoma SAKAMOTO's grave in Reizan Gokoku Shrine.
This ran in the newspapers arousing the morale of the nation, which lead to the establishment of a monument for loyal souls in front of Ryoma SAKAMOTO's grave in Reizan Gokoku Shrine.
This ran in the newspapers arousing the morale of the nation, which lead to the establishment of a monument for loyal souls in front of Ryoma SAKAMOTO's grave in Reizan Gokoku Shrine.

sen.j: その当時の日本女性には珍しく鼻筋の通った顔立ちであり、夫君の明治天皇にからかい混じりに「天狗さん」と渾名されていたという。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken had a sharp nose, which was rare for a Japanese female during her time so her husband, Emperor Meiji, is said to have teasingly nicknamed her "Mrs. Tengu."
Empress Dowager Shoken had a sharp nose, which was rare for a Japanese female during her time, so her husband, Emperor Meiji, is said to have teasingly nicknamed her 'Mrs. Tengu.'
sen.cmt: her timeの後にカンマを入れました。” ” ⇒ ' ' に訂正しました。
sen.e: Empress Dowager Shoken had a sharp nose, which was rare for a Japanese female during her time, so her husband, Emperor Meiji, is said to have teasingly nicknamed her 'Mrs. Tengu.'

sen.j: 追号について
sen.e: About the Empress's posthumous title
About the Empress's posthumous title
About the Empress's posthumous title

sen.j: 皇后・皇太后・太皇太后の3つの身位の班列は、皇族身位令により、1.皇后、2.太皇太后、3.皇太后の順と定められ、諡号・追号には生前帯びていた身位のうち最高のものをつけることになっている。
sen.e: Due to the Kouzokushinirei, the Hanretsu (ministers without official announcement) of the three ranks: Empress, Empress Dowager, and Grand Empress Dowager, are ordered as 1. Empress 2. Grand Empress Dowager 3. Empress Dowager, and for a posthumous title, the highest rank she took during her lifetime is chosen.
sen.cmt: 皇族身位令の適訳がなかったので、kozokushinirei とそのまま書きました。
sen.e: Due to the Kouzokushinirei, the Hanretsu (ministers without official announcement) of the three ranks: Empress, Empress Dowager, and Grand Empress Dowager, are ordered as 1. Empress 2. Grand Empress Dowager 3. Empress Dowager, and for a posthumous title, the highest rank she took during her lifetime is chosen.

Due to the Kouzokushinirei, the Hanretsu (ministers without official announcement) of the three ranks: Empress, Empress Dowager, and Grand Empress Dowager, are ordered as 1. Empress 2. Grand Empress Dowager 3. Empress Dowager, and for a posthumous title, the highest rank she took during her lifetime is chosen.

sen.j: 皇后であった彼女の追号は、本来なら「昭憲皇后」とされるはずであった。
sen.e: Her rightful posthumous title should have been "Empress Shoken" since she was an empress.
Her rightful posthumous title should have been 'Empress Shoken' since she was an empress.
Her rightful posthumous title should have been 'Empress Shoken' since she was an empress.

sen.j: それが「皇太后」になった理由は、孝明天皇の正妻であり明治天皇の「実母」（嫡母）であった英照皇太后の追号が「皇太后」であったことから、誤ってそれに倣って命名してしまったものとされている。
sen.e: The reason she became "Empress Dowager" instead is said to be due to a mistake from following the posthumous title of Emperor Komei's legal wife and Emperor Meiji's "real mother" (biological mother), Empress Dowager Eisho, who was an "Empress Dowager."

The reason she became 'Empress Dowager' instead is said to be due to a mistake from following the posthumous title of Emperor Komei's legal wife and Emperor Meiji's 'real mother' (biological mother), Empress Dowager Eisho, who was an 'Empress Dowager.'

The reason she became 'Empress Dowager' instead is said to be due to a mistake from following the posthumous title of Emperor Komei's legal wife and Emperor Meiji's 'real mother' (biological mother), Empress Dowager Eisho, who was an 'Empress Dowager.'

sen.j: また、皇族身位令の制定が1910年（明治43年）であっていまだその内容が充分に定着していなかったこと、さらに大宝律令の規定ではこれとは違い、1.太皇太后、2.皇太后、3.皇后の順と定められていたことも影響していると考えられる。
sen.e: The fact that the establishment of the Kozokushinirei happened in 1910 so it's contents were not firmly established enough, along with the fact that the regulation of the Taiho Code was different from this and the order was set as 1. Grand Empress Dowager 2. Empress Dowager 3. Empress, also possibly influenced her posthumous title.
sen.cmt: 皇族身位令の適訳がなかったので、kozokushinirei とそのまま書きました。
sen.e: The fact that the establishment of the Kozokushinirei happened in 1910 so it's contents were not firmly established enough, along with the fact that the regulation of the Taiho Code was different from this and the order was set as 1. Grand Empress Dowager 2. Empress Dowager 3. Empress, also possibly influenced her posthumous title.

The fact that the establishment of the Kozokushinirei happened in 1910 so it's contents were not firmly established enough, along with the fact that the regulation of the Taiho Code was different from this and the order was set as 1. Grand Empress Dowager 2. Empress Dowager 3. Empress, also possibly influenced her posthumous title.

sen.j: 英照皇太后は生前女御のままで皇后には冊立されず、明治天皇の即位にともなって皇太后とされたので、その追号は正確なものであったが、昭憲皇太后にはこれは当てはまらない。
sen.e: In life, Empress Dowager Eisho stayed as a consort and was never installed as empress, and she was titled Empress Dowager to accompany Emperor Meiji's enthronement, so this posthumous title is correct, but this does not hold true for Empress Dowager Shoken.

In life, Empress Dowager Eisho stayed as a consort and was never installed as an empress, and she was titled Empress Dowager to accompany Emperor Meiji's enthronement, so this posthumous title is correct, but this does not hold true for Empress Dowager Shoken.
sen.cmt: empress の前に an を追加しました。
sen.e: In life, Empress Dowager Eisho stayed as a consort and was never installed as an empress, and she was titled Empress Dowager to accompany Emperor Meiji's enthronement, so this posthumous title is correct, but this does not hold true for Empress Dowager Shoken.

sen.j: 追号は勅裁により定められたものであるから、誤りが判明しても「綸言汗の如し」としてこれを改めることが出来ず、現在に至っている。
sen.e: A posthumous title is an imperial decision, so even when a mistake is discovered, due to the old belief that what an Emperor says once cannot be taken back, the mistake could not be fixed, and this why this mistake still exists today.
sen.cmt: 「綸言汗の如し」は、その意味だけを訳してあります。
sen.e: A posthumous title is an imperial decision, so even when a mistake is discovered, due to the old belief that what an Emperor says once cannot be taken back, the mistake could not be fixed, and this is why this mistake still exists today.

A posthumous title is an imperial decision, so even when a mistake is discovered, due to the old belief that what an Emperor says once cannot be taken back, the mistake could not be fixed, and this is why this mistake still exists today.

sen.j: 彼女を祭神とする明治神宮は、1920年（大正9年）と1963年（昭和38年）の2度にわたって「昭憲皇后」への改号を宮内省・宮内庁に要請しているが、いずれも拒否された。
sen.e: Meiji-Jingu Shrine, which enshrines the Empress, requested the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Ministry) and Imperial Household Regency for her posthumous title to be changed to "Empress Shoken" two times, in 1920 and 1963, but was denied both times.

Meiji-Jingu Shrine, which enshrines the Empress, requested the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Ministry) and Imperial Household Regency for her posthumous title to be changed to 'Empress Shoken' two times, in 1920 and 1963, but was denied both times.

Meiji-Jingu Shrine, which enshrines the Empress, requested the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Ministry) and Imperial Household Regency for her posthumous title to be changed to 'Empress Shoken' two times, in 1920 and 1963, but was denied both times.

sen.j: 続く貞明皇后と香淳皇后の2人の皇后は、生前皇后であったことを正確に反映した追号を贈られている。
sen.e: The following two empresses, Empress Teimei and Empress Kojun were given a posthumous title which accurately reflected that they were empresses during their lifetime.
The following two empresses, Empress Teimei and Empress Kojun were given a posthumous title which accurately reflected that they were empresses during their lifetime.
The following two empresses, Empress Teimei and Empress Kojun were given a posthumous title which accurately reflected that they were empresses during their lifetime.
